Expectation1: Support each other emotionally during tough times
Situation1: One sibling has just received some very difficult news and is deeply distressed by it.
Expectation2: Diagnose patient illnesses accurately based on symptoms and tests
Situation2: A patient with symptoms of the common cold has come in for a routine check-up.
Story: I sat in my office, white coat still buttoned, when my phone buzzed with a message from my younger brother. The words on the screen made my heart drop—he’d just lost his job, and he was spiraling. He needed me, his big sister, the one who always listened and reassured him that things would be okay. I wanted to call him right away, to be the shoulder he could lean on, but just then, my nurse knocked and ushered in my next patient. The woman coughed and sniffled, her chart in my hands. As a doctor, I was expected to focus, to listen carefully, to make sure her symptoms weren’t masking something more serious. But my mind kept drifting to my brother’s pain, the urge to comfort him warring with my duty to this patient. I felt torn, guilt pressing in from both sides—my family needed me, but so did my patient. I took a deep breath, the weight of both roles heavy on my chest, unsure which part of me should come first.
